title: White-Collar Professional Displacement by 2030
description: Projected percentage of legal, accounting, and financial analyst roles significantly restructured or eliminated by AI by 2030. Only data points where sources directly state a displacement or restructuring figure are plotted.

overlays.label: Goldman Sachs: Administrative and legal professions face highest exposure at 46%
McKinsey: Banking/insurance could see up to 50% of work activities automated
Science RCT: ChatGPT cut task time 40%, raised quality 18%; low-ability workers gain most
BCG/HBS: consultants 12.2% more tasks, 25.1% faster, 40% higher quality with GPT-4
OpenAI/UPenn: ~80% of US workforce could have 10%+ tasks affected; legal among highest
Brookings: most exposed to disruption
WSJ: White-collar workers starting to feel the AI squeeze
HBS: 24% drop in automatable skills demand
NBER: 1 SD increase in AI exposure reduces related skill demand by 2%
JPMorgan: AI in legal/compliance/research yields productivity gains of 3,000+ FTE roles
EY: $1.4B AI investment; AI-assisted audit covers 40% of routine testing tasks
JPMorgan: Non-routine cognitive workers now face rising unemployment risk
Brookings: top freelancers hit hardest
Egon Zehnder: 18% of CFOs already eliminated roles; 88% of cuts in accounting
ILO review: AI exposure highest in high-wage jobs; substitution in writing/translation
BPEA: demand shifting to lower-education roles
Indeed/CNBC: 26% of jobs face radical transformation; paralegals 80% automation risk
Gartner: 50% of middle management positions to be eliminated by 2030
MIT Tech Review: No displacement of lawyers yet; law grad employment at record 93.4%
Deloitte: AI and human collaboration can close talent gaps and speed upskilling
Cognizant: financial managers 84% exposed; legal 63% (up from 9%); C-suite 60% (up from 25%)
Brookings: 56.9M professionals highly adaptive (73%) despite 40% AI exposure
Althoff & Reichardt: Admin roles (financial clerks) see large employment decline

sources.title: The Potentially Large Effects of AI on Economic Growth
sources.excerpt: Two-thirds of US occupations are exposed to some degree of AI automation. Administrative and legal professions face the highest exposure rates at 46%.

sources.title: The economic potential of generative AI: The next productivity frontier
sources.excerpt: Banking, insurance, and capital markets could see up to 50% of current work activities automated. Legal research and contract review are among the most automatable tasks.

sources.title: GPTs are GPTs: An Early Look at the Labor Market Impact Potential of LLMs
sources.excerpt: ~80% of the US workforce could have at least 10% of their tasks affected by GPTs. Legal, accounting, and financial analysis are among the highest-exposure occupations.

sources.title: Which jobs are most exposed to generative AI?
sources.excerpt: High-paid, white-collar occupations in business, finance, and law are among the most exposed to generative AI disruption.

sources.title: AI might not be coming for lawyers' jobs anytime soon
sources.excerpt: Despite early signs that AI is beginning to affect entry-level workers, labor statistics have yet to show lawyers being displaced. Law graduate employment in 2024 reached 93.4% — the highest rate on record.

sources.title: White-Collar Workers Are Starting to Feel the AI Squeeze
Strategies for Workforce Evolution
sources.excerpt: A Deloitte survey reveals how AI and human collaboration can help close talent gaps, speed upskilling, and transfer knowledge as demographic changes reshape the workforce.

sources.title: OECD Employment Outlook 2025: AI and High-Skill Occupations
sources.excerpt: Professional services occupations face the largest task-level AI exposure among high-income economies, with 18-25% of tasks fully automatable by current LLMs.

sources.title: JPMorgan Chase 2024 10-K — AI and Workforce
sources.excerpt: JPMorgan disclosed deploying LLM-based tools across legal, compliance, and research functions, with estimated productivity gains equivalent to 3,000+ full-time roles.

sources.title: EY Global — AI Transformation in Professional Services
sources.excerpt: EY invested $1.4B in AI, reporting that AI-assisted audit procedures now cover 40% of routine testing tasks previously performed by junior staff.

sources.title: 26% of Jobs Face Radical Transformation from AI, Indeed Finds
sources.excerpt: Indeed analysis finds 26% of jobs face radical transformation from AI. Paralegals face 80% automation risk by 2026. Legal research and contract review most affected.

sources.title: Artificial Intelligence and the Labor Market
sources.excerpt: Tasks with higher AI exposure subsequently experience reduced labor demand. 1 SD increase in AI exposure reduces relative demand for related skills by 2%.

sources.title: Technology and Labor Markets: Past, Present, and Future; Evidence from Two Centuries of Innovation
sources.excerpt: In sharp contrast to the past two centuries, AI will shift relative demand toward occupations with lower education, lower wages, and a greater share of male workers.

sources.title: Labor Demand in the Age of Generative AI: Early Evidence from the U.S. Job Posting Data
sources.excerpt: Job postings for high-AI-substitution occupations fell 12% relative to low-substitution roles post-ChatGPT; effect grew from 6% in year one to 18% by year three. Based on 285 million Lightcast job postings.

sources.title: Experimental Evidence on the Productivity Effects of Generative Artificial Intelligence
sources.excerpt: RCT: ChatGPT reduced task completion time by 40% and raised output quality by 18%. Low-ability workers benefited most, compressing the productivity distribution.

sources.title: Displacement or Complementarity? The Labor Market Impact of Generative AI
sources.excerpt: 24% decrease in AI-exposed skills required in highly automatable jobs, but 15% increase in AI-exposed skills for augmentation-prone professional roles.

sources.title: Is Generative AI a Job Killer? Evidence from the Freelance Market
sources.excerpt: High-skill freelancers disproportionately affected by AI — top performers were impacted most, contradicting conventional wisdom that expertise insulates workers.

sources.title: AI and jobs: A review of theory, estimates, and evidence
sources.excerpt: AI exposure measures converge toward high-wage jobs being most exposed; digital trace data show substitution already occurring in writing and translation.

sources.title: AI's Impact on Job Growth
sources.excerpt: Non-routine cognitive job workers now face rising unemployment risk, surpassing non-routine manual workers for the first time.

sources.title: Gartner: 50% of Middle Management Positions to Be Eliminated by 2030
sources.excerpt: Gartner projects 50% of middle management positions will be eliminated or restructured as AI handles reporting, coordination, and performance monitoring tasks.

sources.title: How Will AI Affect the Global Workforce?
sources.excerpt: Only 2.5% of work tasks are currently at risk of direct displacement from AI. Remaining exposure is augmentation-oriented, boosting productivity without eliminating roles.

sources.title: Gartner Top Predictions for IT Organizations 2025
sources.excerpt: Despite widespread AI adoption, less than 1% of enterprise layoffs in 2025 were directly attributed to AI. Most workforce changes are gradual restructuring.

sources.title: AI Revolution: CFOs Forecast a Transformation in Finance Teams
sources.excerpt: 18% of CFOs have already eliminated roles due to AI. Of those, 88% of cuts were in accounting, 38% in FP&A, 33% in treasury. Finance teams are the earliest white-collar AI displacement.

sources.title: Companies Are Laying Off Workers Because of AI's Potential, Not Its Performance
sources.excerpt: 95% of generative AI projects have failed to deliver measurable returns (citing MIT). PwC: 56% of CEOs said AI failed to boost revenue or lower costs. Layoffs are anticipatory, not performance-driven.

sources.title: The Impact of AI on the Legal Profession: Evidence from ChatGPT
sources.excerpt: AI chatbots had no statistically significant impact on hours worked or wages earned for lawyers. Law graduate employment in 2024 reached 93.4% — the highest rate on record.

sources.title: Navigating the Jagged Technological Frontier: Field Experimental Evidence of the Effects of AI on Knowledge Worker Productivity and Quality
sources.excerpt: RCT with 758 BCG consultants: for tasks within AI's capabilities, 12.2% more tasks completed, 25.1% faster, output rated 40% higher quality. For tasks outside AI's frontier, performance was 19pp worse.

sources.title: New Work, New World 2026: How AI is Reshaping Work
sources.excerpt: Education task exposure jumped from 11% to 49% — a 4.5x increase driven by multimodal AI, advanced reasoning, and agentic systems. Based on reassessment of 18,000 tasks across 1,000 O*NET occupations.

sources.title: Task-Specific Technical Change and Comparative Advantage
sources.excerpt: administrative occupations (e.g., financial clerks) see a large decline in employment, while science occupations (e.g., life scientists) expand

sources.title: Measuring US workers' capacity to adapt to AI-driven job displacement
sources.excerpt: Professional and managerial occupations (56.9 million workers) have relatively higher adaptive capacity on average (0.734) despite substantial exposure (0.400).
